name: Spa-Francorchamps - Grand Prix Circuit (F1 Pits)
track_description: This track is known for its fast and flowing nature, with a good mix of high-speed corners and elevation changes.
layout:
Turn 1 (La Source): This is a hairpin where braking stability and low-speed traction are crucial. Opt for a softer front anti-roll bar to aid turn-in and a differential setup that maximizes traction on the exit.

Turn 2 (Eau Rouge): Setup is critical here for maintaining full throttle through the uphill compression. A stable aero balance and stiff suspension will help keep the car planted, but be prepared to lift slightly if the car gets unsettled.

Turn 3 (Raidillon): As the continuation of Eau Rouge, carry the speed through and focus on the exit line as it leads onto the Kemmel Straight. Confidence in the car's stability is key.

Turns 4-5 (Les Combes): This is a heavy braking zone into a chicane. Strong front-end grip is needed for the initial turn-in, and a stable rear is crucial for the quick direction change.

Turn 6 (Malmedy): Exiting Les Combes, carry the momentum and use a late apex for Malmedy to ensure a good exit speed down the following straight.

Turn 7 (Bruxelles): A long, downhill right-hander that tightens on exit. Trail braking helps to rotate the car, and a softer rear setup can aid in maintaining grip throughout the corner.

Turn 8 (Speakers' Corner): A quick corner that requires precision. Maintain a balanced aero setup to keep the car stable through the fast turn.

Turn 9 (Pouhon): A high-speed, double-apex left-hander that demands high downforce for stability and confidence. Minimize steering input to maintain speed and avoid scrubbing off too much through the corner.

Turn 10 (Pouhon): The second apex of Pouhon is crucial for a good exit. Keep the car balanced and aim for a smooth application of the throttle to carry speed onto the following section.

Turns 11-12 (Pif-Paf): This chicane requires a car that can change direction quickly. A stiffer setup may be beneficial, but ensure the car remains compliant enough to deal with the curbs.

Turn 13 (Campus): A corner that follows immediately after the chicane. Keep the car settled and focus on a clean exit to maximize speed onto the following short straight.

Turn 14 (Stavelot): The first part of Stavelot is taken with a focus on setting up for the second part. Use a late apex and prepare for a strong exit.

Turn 15 (Stavelot): The second part is all about the exit as it leads onto the long, full-throttle section of the track. A good differential setup will help put the power down effectively.

Turn 16 (Blanchimont): A very fast corner where aerodynamic efficiency and stability are key. Keep the steering inputs smooth and the throttle controlled to maintain speed through the corner.

Turns 17-18 (Bus Stop Chicane): The final chicane is a heavy braking zone where late braking and strong front-end grip are essential. Attack the curbs but be ready to stabilize the car quickly for the exit onto the start-finish straight.
